2 Tools

The tools section includes a series of mixins, functions, placeholders, etc... to help developers to access settings with ease, do operations with different inputs and reuse concrete behaviors or properties.

2.1 tools.colors

is-coloured($colors)

Creates a set of modifier classes with the whole colors of a colors map passed as a parameter.

  • $colors - A Sass map of colors when the key is the name of the color and the value is the color itself.
Compatibility untested.

2.2 tools.typography

The typography tools includes a series of mixins and functions to work with typographies.

2.3 tools.log

untested

A logger library implemented over the version created by Hugo Giraudel in his article Using @error responsibly in Sass at sitepoint.

The log includes a mixin and a function with the same name. This is a hack needed to allow the log can be called from a function due to Sass doesn't allow calling mixins inside functions.

Note: This module cannot be tested due to the current systems of testing for Sass doesn't allow to test console outputs or compilation breaks.

Variables

var default desc
$log-debug
 No
A constant value used by the log methods to say to the log method that we want to show a debug message in the console.
$log-warn
 No
A constant value used by the log methods to say to the log method that we want to show a warn message in the console.
$log-error
 No
A constant value used by the log methods to say to the log method that we want to show an error message in the console.

Functions

log($message, $type: $log-debug) - the function

The function log launches the directive @debug, @warn or @error depending on the parameter $type passed to the function. It detects if the directive @error is supported (Sass 3.3+) and provides an alternative for lower versions.

parameters
default value
 desc
$message
 No
The message we want to show in the console.
$type
 $log-debug
The type of message we want to show in the console. It could be have the value of one of the variables pre-defined: $log-debug, @log-warn or @log-error.

Usage

If we want to use the logger inside a function we have to use a hack due to the Sass limitations. We should have a code like the one below:

@function myFunction() {
    ...
    @if @log('My log message', $log-error) {}
    ...
}
Compatibility untested.

log($message, $type: $log-debug) - the mixin

Does exactly the same than the function but you can call it like showed in the Usage section.

parameters
default value
 desc
$message
 No
The message we want to show in the console.
$type
 $log-debug
The type of message we want to show in the console. It could be have the value of one of the variables pre-defined: $log-debug, @log-warn or @log-error.

Usage

...
@include('My log message', $log-error);
...
Compatibility untested.
